comment.author: 70251312@N00
comment._content: On December 15, 1913, Diry, a middleweight, was knocked out by George Ashe, in the third round of a contest at the National Sporting Club, in Brooklyn, New York. Diry had come to America from Ireland, where his name was spelled (and pronounced) "Deery." This was his second loss in a row, and he went on to lose three more times by knockouts early in 1914, before hanging up his gloves for good. Diry's boxing record: boxrec.com/list_bouts.php?human_id=73885&cat=boxer New York Times story, December 16, 1913: (NYT says he was a German. NYT also says he had won several earlier fights, but the record contradicts that statement.) query.nytimes.com/mem/archive-free/pdf?_r=1&res=9807E... Other Bain/LOC photos of muscleman Bob Diry: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/library_of_congress/4586271431/] [http://www.flickr.com/photos/library_of_congress/3160154866/]

comment.author: 8560391@N03
comment._content: Hi Wystan. I tend to believe the Diry was indeed German, not Irish, as another NYT link credits him as the German middleweight champion (see his boxrec.com bio). The only source I'm finding that says he's Irish is the info at the top of his boxrec.com record, but I believe that's an error, and I'm also going to guess that whoever compiled his "official" record there got most if not all of the results from the same NYT links we're seeing.
